sub_title: 🌿 Urban Planner, Architect and Researcher specialised in Community-driven Development and Participatory Design 🌿
summary:
🔹 Architect and Urban Planner by education.
🔹 Curious, sensitive and tenacious by nature.
🔹 Creative, plantsperson and traveller by passion.
🔹 International, open-minded and versatile by experience.

Giulia is an urban planner, architect, and researcher specialising in community-driven development and participatory design. She excels at engaging in various kinds of situations, thanks to her international experiences and chameleonic nature. Empathy and curiosity are entirely part of herself, at the same time, the winning cards for building a solid network. After fulfilling diverse responsibilities, from landscape design to applied research, urban planning to event management, she defined her professional goal to help human and non-human communities, co-creating with them more resilient, inclusive, greener public spaces.

school.name: Alma Mater Studiorum – Università di Bologna

certifications.name: DEVELOPMENT AND PLANNING IN AFRICAN CITIES: EXPLORING THEORIES, POLICIES AND PRACTICES FROM SIERRA LEONE

projects.title: SOMALI STUDIES INTERNATIONAL ASSOCIATION CONGRESS
projects.description: Somali Studies International Association was established in 1978. It is an organization that has played a central role in defining the field of modern Somali Studies, and since its establishment, it has organized 12 International Congresses, and many other regional and continental conferences. Out of the 12 International congresses, only four took place in the Somali speaking territories. 40 years later, it is high time for SSIA to hold its Congress in the Horn of Africa. In fact holding 2018 SSIA in Hargeysa will enable Somali studies to reconnect with the current reality on the ground.

contributors.headline: 🌿 Urban Planner, Architect and Researcher specialised in Community-driven Development and Participatory Design 🌿

projects.title: Action Planning Nairobi
projects.description:
The taskforce is to tackle the real life challenges facing Nairobi’s largest informal settlement, Kibera, by developing a multi-stakeholder action plan that is inclusive, tailor-made to the local situation and sustainable.
Creative thinking is vital to success of the exercise as the status quo has not always worked in Kibera. Many initiatives, programme, projects and plans have been implemented to improve the conditions found in Kibera, however the settlement still remains an upgrading conundrum. The action plan developed should be result driven; it should seek new perspectives and/or unconventional ways of thinking and propose innovative bottom-up solutions.

contributors.headline: 🌿 Urban Planner, Architect and Researcher specialised in Community-driven Development and Participatory Design 🌿

projects.title: Tbilisi Courtyards Master Class
projects.description: The Master Class participants developed a multitude of strategies for social and spatial design to rejuvenate these courtyards and rethink their role in the Tbilisi of the 21st century. The goal was to reconsider the social and cultural value of the Tbilisi historical courtyards and to propose urban redevelopment and place-making strategies for these sites; creating a basis for the research and planning method to be used in other districts of old and new Tbilisi in the upcoming years. In just 4 days the teams developed proposals and produced an exposition in a vacant shop on the Agmashenebeli Avenue, where residents, passers-by and professional planners and architects could see the results and engage in lively debates with the designers.

contributors.headline: 🌿 Urban Planner, Architect and Researcher specialised in Community-driven Development and Participatory Design 🌿

projects.title: Tutoring foreign students projects development: Wasteless City workshop
projects.description:
Wasteless City is a hands-on design workshop that was organized and produced by The New Raw for the Honk Kong Design Institute during the visit of the 2nd year architectural students in the city of Rotterdam (21-22 Nov 2016).

Plastic packaging is the largest contributor to plastic pollution. More than 90% of all plastic packaging is made from only four types of thermoplastics (PET, HDPE, LDPE, PP).

The workshop investigated four types of commodity plastics and examined the ability of low- and high tech- fabrication methods to provide new solutions for plastic recycle and develop concepts that follow the principles of circular economy.

contributors.headline: 🌿 Urban Planner, Architect and Researcher specialised in Community-driven Development and Participatory Design 🌿

projects.title: C-HR Berlin Innovation & Creativity Festival - Berlin, Germany
projects.description:
Recycled park is the proposal to retrieve plastic waste from the river the Nieuwe Maas just before it reaches the North Sea. The plastics are recycled to give new value to the river.
From the plastics we construct floating platforms  for a new green environment; a floating park.
The  Recycled Park is the first floating recycled park in the world.
We are working together with partners in Belgium and England to also implement the principle of Recycled Park in London and Antwerp: river pollution is retrieved before it reaches the sea. 
The plastics are recycled as building material for new floating nature landscapes that improve the ecosystem in the river and the living environment in the city.

contributors.headline: 🌿 Urban Planner, Architect and Researcher specialised in Community-driven Development and Participatory Design 🌿

projects.title: Final Academic Projects, Architectural Design Exposition - Izmir, Turkey
projects.description:
Kusadası is a resort town on Turkey’s Aegean coast, which primarily relies on tourism.
The project strategy concerns the combined design of the port and the surrounding area, which need to be connected and work together. The project focuses on the cruise port area, and the goal of the design is to provide a new identity to the Kusadasi coast line, by giving a more attractive look to the cruise port. These changes aim at making Kusadasi coast line the focal point of the city.
The approach to the project begins with the site analysis, which involves the whole waterfront and the inside areas. Moreover, there was a need to create a variety of services, lacking in the area, such as continuous connective paths for vehicles, cyclists and pedestrian, resting, eating and touristic points, as well as a gathering square.
The main challenge is the organization of all the cruise port services and facilities, since they have to be located in a zone that is going to become the centre of the city. Currently the project site does not have an important role concerning the city life, however with the new proposal, the locals and the visitors
can use the space and create full year benefits from the port.
The building functions and facilities are hidden by a green terrace, which is for public use, passengers as well as citizens. The specific feature is represented by possibility of being a structure in use for 12 months per year, thanks to the mushroom structure shelters that offer a shaded spot during the hot season.

contributors.headline: 🌿 Urban Planner, Architect and Researcher specialised in Community-driven Development and Participatory Design 🌿

projects.title: URBAN STRATEGIES AND PLANNING WORKSHOP: Food and the City - Rotterdam, The Netherlands
projects.description:
Investigation on ‘Food’ in one of Rotterdam’s neighbourhood, in collaboration with the students from Urban Strategy and Planning specialization and the supervision of Dr. Alexander Jachnow. 
The theme Food and the City was developed around SDG 11 for safe, inclusive cities and Rotterdam 2030 urbanization plan while considering a 3% per annum population growth rate (growth scenario). The research approaches included: spatial, socioeconomic and governance assessments which ultimately led to the development of a strategic plan and recommendations for the political decision makers and other agencies. The baseline assessment used both primary and secondary data in the form of stakeholder engagement to desktop reviews and even a simulation exercise which aided in development of neighbourhood profile. The spatial assessment demonstrated how the physical transformation of neighbourhoods can contribute to inequality in the case of Ijsselmonde both socially and economically. On these tenets the study was further developed. 
The scenario building utilized two variables from each thematic area to project how an increase and or decrease in either can affect the city, demonstrating 4 possible outcomes for each thematic area. Stakeholders were particularly important throughout the entire process, but the conference/workshop in particular, was dependent on the feedback gained. The feedback given was used to develop a strategic plan that would address some of the more important issues identified. 
The strategy addressed issues of capacity building, raising awareness and livelihood opportunities through urban agricultural initiatives.

GLUT - Gaining through Land Use Transactions Workshop: Application of academic perspective to understand why and how cities evolve within different context and periods (urban theory, complexity theory, urban economic/social/environmental d
Living Labs Workshop: Learning the concepts of Living Labs and its group work tools in urban planning.
Placemaking for Future Food in Growing Rotterdam Workshop: Learning the strategic value of placemaking analytical toolkit, applicable to urban strategy and real settings.

Urban Governance, Policy, Planning, Public Private Partnership

profile_positions.description: This research project seeks to facilitate the transition of urban designers from a human-centric design paradigm to a nature-inclusive approach. The objective is to address the pressing challenges posed by the climate crisis by adopting innovative design perspectives that prioritise the needs of non-human entities. By placing non-human agents at the core of the design process, this project aims to support urban designers in effectively tackling the climate crisis through research through design methodologies.
profile_positions.title: PHD Candidate

profile_positions.description: Part of the research team Urban Innovation at Hogeschool Windesheim, Almere.
profile_positions.title: Researcher

profile_positions.description: Giulia is a partner at Huasipichanga, a transdisciplinary urban consultancy that aims to encourage citizen ownership of urban spaces and motivate the progressive development of inclusive societies. She contributes globally to the consolidation of sustainable, resilient and inclusive urban practices by supporting people in identifying their local identity and strengths. Her primary interests are public space and communities, especially in the Global South. She truly believes in co-design and co-creating urban solutions with local participation and multistakeholder engagement. Since 2019, she has advocated for child-responsive planning and design as part of the Huasipichanga team and as leader of the Placemaking Europe network, initiating awareness campaigns, organizing interactive workshops and developing methodologies and tools for more child-friendly public spaces. Last year, she contributed to Ecuador, Italy, Mexico, Germany, the Netherlands, Spain, Turkey and Senegal.
profile_positions.title: Partner, Urban Development Strategist and Planner

profile_positions.description:
Simeri Laboratorio Urbano is an experimental practice for the regeneration of rural landscapes and reactivation of public spaces and public life in the small Calabrian village of Simeri, Italy. 

We are a collective acting in a local and international network and applying a co-creative approach based on a strong sense of community and local cooperation. We are a passionate team of different backgrounds, spanning from architecture, landscape architecture, urban planning and design, archaeology and journalism, sharing the mission of creating better spaces for people. 

Through various formats (exhibitions, workshops, interventions etc.), we will collaborate with local citizens to identify the true potential of Simeri. The aim? Co-create a future vision to sustain this fantastic place facing typical rural issues like demographic change, population decline and decay. 

Cooperating with the local association APS Asperitas that is working on promoting cultural and environmental heritage in Calabria, we are grounded right on the spot in the community of Simeri.
profile_positions.title: Urban Planner

profile_positions.company: AUAS - Civic Interaction Design Research Group
profile_positions.description:
Researcher in the research group Civic Interaction Design. Involved in the project 'From Prevention to Resilience: Designing Public Spaces in Times of Pandemics'.

This project explores and investigates the question: how can design interventions in public space for the 1.5-meter society also contribute to strengthening social and ecological resilience?
profile_positions.title: Junior Researcher

profile_positions.description: Giulia is the Assistant Project Manager at City Space Architecture in the project A-Place. Linking places through networked artistic practices, co-funded by the Creative Europe programme of the European Commission, dedicated to strengthening the bonds between people and places (2019-2023). In particular, she assists the management of the international film festival “Urban Vision. Beyond the Ideal City” (UV) which will include a competition for short films, with sections dedicated to specific themes and several travelling cinema events, enhanced with exhibitions, public talks and art-based performances.
profile_positions.title: Assistant Project Manager

company.name: European School of Urban Game Design

profile_positions.company: European School of Urban Game Design
profile_positions.description:
The European School od Urban Game Design - "Trust in Play" supports emerging professionals in urban game design, mentoring them to build a sustainable practice and playfully explore new relationships of trust in cities.
Giulia is also a trainee of the European School of Urban Game Design – Trust in Play – since summer 2019 - a program that has been allowing her to advance her design skills and digital knowledge in regards to public space while deepening her understanding in creative processes to develop cross-disciplinary outcomes. During the last year, she has been involved in the creation of two urban games prototypes, Anxcity, and Snake City. They both represent games based on interaction and participation design. Besides, they empower people to experience public spaces and test the feelings of trust that they have for each other and for the technology itself.
profile_positions.title: Trainee

profile_positions.description:
STIPO is an interdisciplinary team for urban development and placemaking. STIPO offers an open window to a better city. We work on area development, citywide strategies, social innovation, the city at eye level and placemaking. We work for cities, communities and civic initiatives, private developers, NGOs and knowledge institutes. We are based in Amsterdam, Rotterdam, Stockholm and Thessaloniki. | www.stipo.nl | 

Within Europe, we are the co-founder of the European Placemaking Network, and of the network re:Kreators.

We are initiators of The City at Eye Level, a worldwide programme for improving cities, streets and places. We let buildings contribute to the quality of public space with their ground floors (the city at eye level). We turn streets, plazas and areas into places where people feel at home and want to stay (placemaking). With local communities, we develop and implement strategies for human scale in cities, area development, streets and plazas (co-creation). The method combines use, design and organisation (software, hardware and orgware).

With knowledge as a fundament, we help cities and their partners to develop strategies to create and improve their own great City at Eye Level. We share our knowledge open source, online and through the City at Eye Level books. | www.thecityateyelevel.com |
profile_positions.title: Communication, Community management and Placemaking

company.name: EARF (East Africa Research Fund) and DfID (Department of International Development)

profile_positions.company: EARF (East Africa Research Fund) and DfID (Department of International Development)
profile_positions.description: The objective of the research is to explore the spatial inequalities through Complex Land Markets in 4 cities in Uganda and Somaliland. It will investigate the urban transition of these fast-growing cities by assessing the role of urban land markets, being understood as multiple and complex in producing or reducing inequalities. The research seeks to develop a more holistic understanding of how these cities work as and within integrated systems. In this understanding, the social and legal components of land markets institutionalise diverse practices of land transactions presenting an informal-formal continuum. CLM is an institution that has substituted to a significant extent the merely formal, partially dysfunctional land governance institutions.
profile_positions.title: Junior Researcher in collaboration with IHS, Erasmus Unievrsity Rotterdam

volunteer_experiences.description:
Placemaking Europe is the not-for-profit network focused on strengthening placemaking and the city at eye level in Europe.  

Placemaking Europe brings placemakers together during the annual Placemaking Week Europe and other meetings.  We collect and share best practices via the website, books and articles. We build an open-source placemaking toolbox together with the network. We teach and do talks. We are practitioners, we use our knowledge of projects. We work in better cities and assist governments, market parties, knowledge institutions, social organizations and others who need our help. We build on the knowledge program of the City at Eye Level that STIPO initiated in 2012.

Since 2019, she advocates for child-responsive planning and design, as part of Huasipichanga team and leader of Placemaking Europe network, by initiating awareness campaigns, organizing interactive workshops and developing methodologies and tools for more child-friendly public spaces. During the last year, she brought her contribution to Italy, Mexico, Germany, the Netherlands, Spain and Senegal.

MISSION - We are a global network of leaders who together accelerate placemaking as a way to create healthy, inclusive, and beloved communities.

VISION - To make the spaces we live into places we love. Create a thriving, equitable, and sustainable world through the convergence of values, passion, and action around our public spaces.

NETWORK - We are a collective-impact network of placemaking thought leaders, public space activists, regional network leaders, and professionals from all over the world. We have diverse experiences and backgrounds but share a common purpose.

company.name: ISOCARP - International Society of City and Regional Planners

volunteer_experiences.description: The International Society of City and Regional Planners (ISOCARP) is a global association of experienced professional city and regional planners. ISOCARP was founded in 1965 in a bid to bring together recognised and highly-qualified planners in an international network.
Expert in gender and just distribution of land resources in Somalia.
